body_html:
@amohant4 have you got a solution for the case above?

I want to get gradients w.r.t. a subset of a variable, like tf.gradients([loss], [variable[i]] but this returns None as slicing returns a new tensor. This is closely related to this stackoverflow question.

I want to get gradients w.r.t. a subset of a variable, like tf.gradients([loss], [variable[i]] but this returns None as slicing returns a new tensor. This is closely related to this stackoverflow question.
body:
@amohant4 have you got a solution for the case above? 

I want to get gradients w.r.t. a subset of a variable, like tf.gradients([loss], [variable[i]] but this returns None as slicing returns a new tensor. This is closely related to this [stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41889531/slice-of-a-variable-returns-gradient-none).
